Yes, there have been some notable success stories in recent history where governments have been able to effectively stimulate their economies during times of political instability or economic downturns. Here are a few examples:

1. South Korea: In the aftermath of the Asian financial crisis in the late 1990s, South Korea implemented a series of sweeping economic reforms and implemented measures to stabilize their financial sector. These reforms included corporate restructuring, labor market reforms, and increased transparency and accountability in the financial sector. These policy changes helped to restore investor confidence and paved the way for a renewed period of economic growth in South Korea.

2. Germany: Following the 2008 financial crisis, the German government implemented a package of measures aimed at stimulating the economy, including tax cuts, increases in infrastructure spending, and subsidies for renewable energy. These measures helped to stabilize the economy and prevent a recession, and Germany has since enjoyed steady economic growth.

3. Australia: In response to the economic impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic, the Australian government implemented a series of measures aimed at stimulating the economy and supporting businesses and households. These measures included wage subsidies, investment incentives, and direct payments to households. As a result, Australia has been able to avoid a recession and has experienced a rebound in economic activity.

Of course, the success of these policies depends on a range of factors, including the specific circumstances of each country and the effectiveness of the policy measures themselves.
